resource.chars:
In the <u>Insecta <\u>, urea is sometimes present and 
sometimes absent in the fluid of the Malpighian 
tubules. The author has extracted urea from the 
Malpighian tubules of <u>Periplaneta <\u>;* but this nitrogen-
ous compound is entirely absent in the same organs 
of <u>Libellula depressa <\u>.+ Uric acid is, however, present 
in the Malpighian tubules of both these orthopter-
ous insects.
Concerning the renal organs of <u>Pontia brassicae <\u>,
the author gives the following account:-
Under the microscope, a Malpighian tubule of <u>Pontia <\u>
[is] seen to consist of a connective tissue layer, a
delicate “tracheal tube “, a basement membrane,
and an epithelium layer of comparatively large 
nucleated cells (Fig.4). The internal cavity of one 
of these tubules is very irregular, as is seen by ex-
amining various parts of it in a transverse section.
[*] Griffiths, <u>Chemical News <\u>, vol.52, p.195.
[+] Griffiths, <u>Proc. Roy. Soc.  Edinb., vol.15, p.401.
